taxonomicNotes: Several genetic experiments have suggested that Takifugu chinensis and T. rubripes are very closely related and can possibly be regarded as the same species (Reza et al. 2011). In China, T. chinensis is considered to be a junior synonym of Takifugu pseudommus. However, differences in the anal fin color of these two species makes it unlikely that they are the same species (Matsuura pers. comm. 2011). Skull structure of the two species is identical, however, and therefore further taxonomic studies are required. The economically important genus Takifugu has been recommended for further taxonomic studies based on morphological and molecular analyses (Yamanoue et al. 2008). We accept the taxonomic validity of T. chinensis.

There is some controversy concerning the taxonomy and nomenclature of Squatina species of the Southwest Atlantic. Squatina occulta described by Vooren and da Silva (1991) has been regarded as being a junior synonym of S. guggenheim by Soto (2001) in a species-level checklist of the region. Although evidence was not given to support this statement, Bernardes et al. (2005) followed Soto’s proposal. However, later studies have re-evaluated the species’ validity. The validity of S. occulta Vooren and da Silva, 1991 as a distinct species has been confirmed through the study of mitochondrial DNA by Stelbrink et al. (2010) and in a comparative study of Southwest Atlantic Squatina neurocrania (Carvalho et al. 2012). Both studies also recognized S. argentina, S. guggenheim, and S. occulta as the only valid species in the Southwest Atlantic (preceding the description of new species since that time, S. david and S. varii).

Some confusion exists regarding the publication date of the description of S. occulta (Faria et al. 2014). Some taxonomic literature sources list 1991 as the publication date while others list 1992. This confusion is probably due to the distribution of pre-prints of the article in 1991 before the full issue of the journal was printed in 1992. According to The International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature, the publication date of the S. occulta description is 1991. There has also been discrepancy in referencing the species authority for S. occulta, particularly the name of the second author (Faria et al. 2014); K.G. da Silva’s surname has been spelled ‘da Silva’, ‘Da Silva’, and ‘Silva’. Faria et al. (2014) suggested using the one in the revisions by Vaz and Carvalho (2013) and in online taxonomic databases. Thus, the recommended citation is S. occulta Vooren & da Silva, 1991.
Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.
Castro (2011) resurrected Carcharhinus cerdale, considering it distinct from C. porosus. Carcharhinus cerdale is restricted to the Eastern Pacific and C. porosus to the Western Atlantic.

Dipturus diehli Soto & Mincarone, 2001, as known only from the holotype taken off Santa Catarina, Brazil (29°39´S, 47°50´W) at a depth of 480 m, is likely a synonym of D. mennii and is treated here as such.
The Adriatic population described as a subspecies and may have been a conservation unit, is now extinct.

According to Fernholm (1986, 1998), E. octatrema was only known from the 300 mm holotype. In the original description, Barnard (1923) apparently described only one specimen, but he stated “…ventral fin ending only a short distance (8-10 mm) behind last gill-opening”. The range “8-10 mm” could be evidence that there were at least two specimens used for the description. In addition, the only other known specimen BMNH 1927.12.6.1 (formerly SAM 13031) is listed as "co-type" in the original register. According to the SAM database (M. Bougaardt pers. comm.), the station data for these specimens are: SAM 13030, Cape Saint Blaize, North 1/4 North, 6.5 miles, 36 fm (66 m), 28 June 1899, shrimp trawl, RV Pieter Faure; and BMNH 1927.12.6.1 [ex SAM 13031], Cape Saint Blaize, West 3/4 North, 4 miles, 27 fm (49 m), 25 January 1900, trawl, RV Pieter Faure. Based on this evidence, both specimens are considered here as syntypes of E. octatrema. Also, the type locality provided in Barnard’s (1923) original description (“Agulhas Bank, 25-40 fm”) is an assumed approximation.
Giant sea bass was originally assigned to the grouper family, Serranidae, but was later placed in a new family called the Percichthyidae (Domeier 2001).

Archaelogical remains suggest that A. sturio colonised the Baltic Sea about 3,000 years ago from the North Sea, and vanished from the Baltic Sea about 800 years ago. Climatic changes about 100 years ago (Little Ice Age) might have had an impact indirectly in favouring introgression by hybridization with A. oxyrinchus.

Molecular studies strongly suggest that Russian Sturgeon (Acipenser gueldenstaedtii) is very closely related to Persian Sturgeon (Acipenser persicus), and it cannot be excluded that these two taxa are conspecific.

Molecular studies strongly suggest that Persian Sturgeon (Acipenser persicus) is very closely related to Russian Sturgeon (Acipenser gueldenstaedtii) and it cannot be excluded that these two taxa are conspecific.

The Chinese Sturgeon Acipenser sinensis is restricted to the main channel of the Yangtze and the Pearl rivers and the East and South China Seas. Though there is still disagreement about the taxonomy of the Pearl and Yangtze River populations, Chinese scholars commonly divide Chinese Sturgeon into two populations; one is the Pearl River Chinese Sturgeon, which spawns in spring, and is close to dying out. The other is the Yangtze River Chinese Sturgeon, which spawns in autumn and still maintains a certain amount below the Gezhouba Dam.
The taxonomic status of the species has only recently been clarified. Previously, it was considered conspecific with North American Green Sturgeon (A. medirostris) (Shmigirilov 2007).
Sometimes known as Cephaloscyllium sarawakense (Fricke et al. 2020).
The subgenus Leucoraja was elevated to genus rank by McEachran and Dunn (1998).

Changes to the systematics of Rhinobatos elevated the subgenus Glaucostegus to full generic status and placed this genus into a family of its own: Glaucostegidae (Compagno 2005, Last et al. 2016a). This species is often confused with Glaucostegus typus and Pacific Ocean records of G. granulatus are probably G. typus.

Recent changes to the systematics of Rhinobatos have elevated the subgenus Glaucostegus to full generic status and placed this genus into a family of its own: Glaucostegidae (Compagno 2005, Last et al. 2016a).

Glaucostegus microphthalamus is currently considered a synonym of G. typus (W.T. White and D.A. Ebert pers. comm. 2016).

Rhynchobatus australiae is part of the Indo-West Pacific Rhynchobatus djiddensis species-complex. The name R. djiddensis has previously been used widely, leading to poorly-defined taxonomy and distributions for members of the complex (in particular, R. australiae, R. djiddensis, and R. laevis). Further investigation into the taxonomy of 'whitespotted wedgefish' is required, and additional species are likely to be described in the future.

The Flapper Skate (Dipturus intermedius) and Common Blue Skate (Dipturus batis) were synonymised in a taxonomic revision of European skates (Rajidae) in the 1920s (Clark 1926), before being recognised again as separate species in 2010 (Iglésias et al. 2010). Consequently, information for both species were reported as ‘Dipturus batis’ (the 'common skate complex') for much of the 20th and early 21st centuries.

The genus Lucifuga is one of the most diverse stygiobiotic genera of fishes to have been described. The taxonomy of Lucifuga species may still be incomplete due to relatively common discoveries of new species. García-Machado et al. (2011) concluded that Lucifuga spp. are genetically divergent, but most closely related lineages are morphologically indistinguishable and recommend revisiting the taxonomy of the genus. Since the distribution of certain morphological characters among these species is disjointed, they possibly may not be used for classification in the future. A description of a new species, Lucifuga gibarensis of Cuba, was recently published (Hernández et al. 2020).

This species was previously confused with other guitarfishes and erroneously considered to be widespread in the Indo-Pacific. Rhinobatos formosensis from Taiwan is now known to be a junior synonym of R. schlegelii (Last et al. 2016a, Last et al. 2016b).
The species is distinguished from its regional congeners, the Bottlennose Guitarfish (Rhinobatos schlegelii) by colour, morphology, and meristic characters (Last et al. 2014).

The taxonomy of the 'whitespotted wedgefish' species-complex (which includes several Indo-West Pacific wedgefishes) is not fully resolved, and the status of the Taiwanese Wedgefish is in need of critical re-evaluation by comparing it to other regional species.

authority: Ruocco, Lucifora, Díaz de Astarloa, Mabragaña & Delpiani, 2012

taxonomicNotes:
Recent changes to the systematics of Rhinobatos have elevated the subgenus Glaucostegus to full generic status and placed this genus into a family of its own: Glaucostegidae (Compagno 2005, Last et al. 2016a).

Séret and McEachran (1986) tentatively synonymised Glaucostegus petiti (reported from the Western Indian Ocean) with G. cemiculus because the morphometrics and the meristics of the holotype and only known specimen of G. petiti fell into the ranges of variation of G. cemiculus. Glaucostegus cemiculus is an Eastern Atlantic species, however, and does not occur in the Western Indian Ocean from which G. petiti is reported (Bernard Séret pers. comm. 2008). It is possible that there was a mistake in the origin of the type specimen, although the collector Georges Petit did explore the Tuléar region of Madagasar. No further specimens of Glaucostegus petiti have been found to date, despite the presence of an active research station in Tuléar for decades, although other guitarfishes (Acroteriobatus annulatus and Rhinobatos holcorhynchus) have been collected from the region (Bernard Séret pers. comm. 2008).

Glaucostegus petiti is considered a synonym of G. cemiculus (William T. White and David A. Ebert pers. comm. 2016).

Last et al. (2016) placed Dasyatis colarensis, D. garouaensis, D. geijskesi, D. margarita, D. margaritella, and Urogymnus ukpan within their newly described genus Fontitrygon. The two Western Atlantic species (F. colarensis and F. geijskesi) differ significantly from the other taxa in this genus and may prove to be non-congeneric with the four species from West Africa (Last et al. 2016).

This species is often mistaken with Hypanus guttatus but snout length and pelvic fin shape differ.

Last et al. (2016) placed Dasyatis colarensis, D. garouaensis, D. geijskesi, D. margarita, D. margaritella, and Urogymnus ukpan within their newly described genus Fontitrygon. The two Western Atlantic species (F. colarensis and F. geijskesi) differ significantly from the other taxa in this genus and may prove to be non-congeneric with the four species from West Africa (Last et al. 2016).
Last et al. (2016a) placed Dasyatis colarensis, D. garouaensis, D. geijskesi, D. margarita, D. margaritella, and Urogymnus ukpan within their newly described genus Fontitrygon.

Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, elevating the former subgenus Acroteriobatus to generic status.

Acroteriobatus variegatus is morphologically very similar to A. zanzibarensis, with only subtle differences in mitochondrial DNA between the two species. Further work is required to clarify their relationship (Last et al. 2016b).

Previously Torpedo suessi was considered a junior synonym of T. sinuspersici (Carvalho et al. 2002). Garman (1913) considered T. suessi to be a valid species, but thought that it may be synonymous with T. panthera. However, Carvalho et al. (2002) believe that this is not possible due to the inconceivability that the ornate colour pattern of T. suessi could transform into the typical pattern of small, irregular whitish spots present in T. panthera. Rather than being a synonym of T. sinuspersici, or T. panthera, it is much more likely that T. suessi is a valid species that occurs at least in the southern Red Sea (Carvalho et al. 2002). This species may also be identifiable with the paralectotype of T. fuscomaculata, but there is some uncertainty surrounding this, and T. suessi would still prove to be a valid species even it if it was conspecific with the paralectotype (Carvalho et al. 2002).

The Lost Shark is a recently described, distinct, whaler shark of the Carcharhinus porosus subgroup (White et al. 2019a). Originally described as Carcharhinus obsolerus, the correct spelling is actually Carcharhinus obsoletus (Dubois and Seret 2019, White et al. 2019b).

The Java Stingaree is known only from the type specimen and is considered valid with the holotype housed at the Humboldt-Universität, Museum für Naturkunde, Zoologisches Museum, Berlin, Germany. It is a unique species of stingaree and its placement in the genus Urolophus is provisional (Last et al. 2016). It is the only known stingaree (family Urolophidae) from Java; the Kai Stingaree (Urolophus kaianus), the only other stingaree known from Indonesia, doesn't overlap with the historical range of the Java Stingaree (Last et al. 2016).
Squatina aculeata is difficult to identify to the species level, therefore many of the records from fisher reports are often assigned only to the genus level. Misidentification is common.
Squatina oculata is difficult to identify to the species level, therefore many of the records from fishermen reports are often assigned only to genus level.

The Chilean Angelshark (Squatina armata), has previously been considered to be conspecific with the Pacific Angelshark (S. californica). Recent molecular evidence places S. armata as the sister taxon to the Neotropical angel sharks, indicating it is a distinct species (Stelbrink et al. 2010). Given its prior taxonomic placement, some literature on the elasmobranch fauna of Peru, Ecuador, and Colombia list S. californica as part of their coastal fauna, while others only mention S. armata. To add to the confusion, some country checklists include both S. armata and S. californica (see Cornejo et al. 2015). These records of S. californica occurring sympatrically with S. armata are likely incorrect, thus for the purpose of this assessment all angel shark records in the Southeast Pacific are considered to be S. armata. Further research is needed to elucidate the distributions of S. armata and S. californica, particularly in the Pacific coast of Central America and the northwest coast of South America.

There is some controversy concerning the taxonomy and nomenclature of Squatina species of the Southwest Atlantic. Squatina occulta described by Vooren and da Silva (1991) has been regarded as being a junior synonym of S. guggenheim by Soto (2001) in a species-level checklist of the region. Although evidence was not given to support this statement, Bernardes et al. (2005) followed Soto’s proposal. However, later studies have re-evaluated the species’ validity. The validity of S. occulta Vooren and da Silva, 1991 as a distinct species has been confirmed through the study of mitochondrial DNA by Stelbrink et al. (2010) and in a comparative study of Southwest Atlantic Squatina neurocrania (Carvalho et al. 2012). Both studies also recognized S. argentina, S. guggenheim, and S. occulta as the only valid species in the Southwest Atlantic (preceding the description of new species since that time, S. david and S. varii).

Angel sharks (Squatina spp.) in the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean are difficult to identify to species level, therefore many of the records from fishermen reports in the Mediterranean are often assigned only to genus level. Squatina squatina is the only species to occur in the Northeast Atlantic from Portugal northwards.

Rhynchobatus djiddensis is part of the Indo-West Pacific Rhynchobatus djiddensis species-complex. The name R. djiddensis has previously been used widely, leading to poorly-defined taxonomy and distributions for members of the complex (in particular, R. australiae, R. djiddensis, and R. laevis). Further investigation into the taxonomy of 'whitespotted wedgefish' is required, and additional species are likely to be described in the future.
Brachionichthys australis and B. hirsutus are similar in appearance, but are confirmed to be separate species (Last et al. 2007).
The genus Thymichthys is relatively new, and needs further taxonomic resolution (Last and Gledhill 2009).

Glyphis gangeticus was originally described from the Hooghly River, India. Records of G. gangeticus are sparse and there have been previous issues with reporting due to misidentification with other carcharhinds, mainly the Bull Shark (Carcharhinus leucas) and Broadfin sharks (Lamiopsis spp.), resulting in historic ambiguities about the range of G. gangeticus. The taxonomic status of the species was recently resolved with Li et al. (2015) demonstrating that G. siamensis and G. fowlerae are synonyms of G. gangeticus. Based on molecular data, there is an undescribed Glyphis species currently known from Bangladesh and Malaysian Borneo (Li et al. 2015).

Rhynchobatus laevis is part of the Indo-West Pacific Rhynchobatus djiddensis species-complex. The name R. djiddensis has previously been used widely, leading to poorly-defined taxonomy and distributions for members of the complex (in particular, R. australiae, R. djiddensis, and R. laevis). Rhynchobatus yentinensis Wang, 1933 (described from China) might be applicable to this species or may be a synonym of R. springeri. Further investigation into the taxonomy of 'whitespotted wedgefish' is required, and additional species are likely to be described in the future.
White (2014) placed the genus Pteromylaeus Garman, 1913 into the synonymy of Aetomylaeus Garman, 1908. This species is often confused with Common Eagle Ray (Myliobatus aquila).

Rhynchobatus springeri is part of the Indo-West Pacific Rhynchobatus djiddensis species-complex. The name R. djiddensis has previously been used widely, leading to poorly-defined taxonomy and distributions for members of the complex (in particular, R. australiae, R. djiddensis, and R. laevis). Further investigation into the taxonomy of 'whitespotted wedgefish' is required, and additional species are likely to be described in the future. 

Rhynchobatus yentinensis Wang, 1933 (described from China) might be applicable to this species or may be a synonym of R. laevis.
Changes to the systematics of Rhinobatos elevated the subgenus Glaucostegus to full generic status and placed this genus into a family of its own: Glaucostegidae (Compagno 2005, Last et al. 2016a).
Gymnura tentaculata identified from Papua New Guinea (Kailola 1987) are a misidentification of G. australis, as G. tentaculata appears to be restricted to the Northern Indian Ocean.

It is unclear whether this, or a similar, species occurs along the east and west African coasts and Mediterranean Sea. A systematic review of this species is needed in these areas. This species is sometimes confused with Duckbill Eagle Ray (Aetomylaeus bovinus).
The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis (Kottelat, 2013); it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016a) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.
Séret and Naylor (2016) described Rhynchorhina mauritaniensis (and Rhynchorhina as a new genus) from limited specimens collected off Mauritania (Eastern Central Atlantic).

This species is often misidentified with other regional Squatinids. Diagnostic features for Squatina japonica include pelvic fin tips which do not reach the first dorsal origin and spines along the midback line (Walsh et al. 2011).
There is ongoing discussion amongst workers since some hamlet species have been known to produce hybrids (Victor and Marks 2018).

In a recent study, Faria et al. (2013) demonstrated that the existing taxonomy of the Pristidae required modification, recognising a total of five species in two genera. Pristis pristis had been recognised previously as consisting of up to three species (Pristis pristis, P. microdon and P. perotteti), but utilising a combination of mitochondrial DNA and morphological characters appears to be one species. While the P. pristis group is best considered a single species, it can be composed of a network of geographical units (subpopulations) that are not genetically distinct, but may be considered ecologically different.
 
Pristis pristis, has been referred to by many other names throughout its range. It was formerly known as P. perotteti in the Atlantic and sometimes in the Eastern Pacific, and P. microdon in the Indo-West Pacific.

Faria et al. (2013) state that both morphology and genetics support the current specific status of the Smalltooth Sawfish (Pristis pectinata) and propose modification of the distribution of the species to an Atlantic only range. No geographical structure of Smalltooth Sawfish subpopulations is present, and Western and Eastern Atlantic subpopulations of Smalltooth Sawfish likely represent separate units for conservation purposes.
Recent taxonomic work has confirmed that the Green Sawfish (Pristis zijsron) is a valid species with an Indo-West Pacific distribution (Faria et al. 2013).
Castro (2011) resurrected Carcharhinus cerdale, considering it distinct from Carcharhinus porosus. Carcharhinus cerdale is restricted to the Eastern Pacific and C. porosus to the Western Atlantic.
The Clown Wedgefish is a recently described small species of wedgefish (Last et al. 2016). It is a distinct species which is not likely to be confused with other Rhynchobatus species.

Other Anguilla species have occasionally been stocked in Europe, but none have established a self-sustaining population. Pure A. rostrata (American Eel) have been recorded but are relatively rare (Boëtius 1976). Stocking attempts are likely to have caused this (Frankowski et al. 2008, Marohn et al. 2014). DNA analysis is the best tool to distinguish between the European Eel and other species (e.g. Frankowski et al. 2008), but A. rostrata have fewer vertebrae than A. anguilla (102–112, usually 106–108, vs. 111–119, usually 114–116). Hybrids have been found as larvae in the Sargasso Sea (Als et al. 2011, Pujolar et al. 2014a) and as yellow eels in Iceland where pure A. rostrata and A. anguilla also exist (Albert et al. 2006).
Previously confused with the Whitespotted Whipray (Maculabatis gerrardi) from which it can be distinguished based on colour and morphometrics (Manjaji-Matsumoto and Last 2016).
There are nuclear and mitochondrial genetic markers available for the identification of this species and its hybrids.

The Common Blue Skate (Dipturus batis) and Flapper Skate (Dipturus intermedius) were synonymised in a taxonomic revision of European skates (Rajidae) in the 1920s (Clark 1926), before being recognised again as separate species in 2010 (Iglésias et al. 2010). Consequently, information for both species were reported as ‘Dipturus batis’ (the 'common skate complex') for much of the 20th and early 21st centuries.
Records of this species off Argentina refer to Mustelus schmitti.

Recent changes to the systematics of Rhinobatos have elevated the subgenus Glaucostegus to full generic status and placed this genus into a family of its own: Glaucostegidae (Compagno 2005, Last et al. 2016a). Reports of G. obtusus from South Africa are considered invalid and based on other species (Compagno and Last 1999).

Recent changes to the systematics of Rhinobatos have elevated the subgenus Glaucostegus to full generic status and placed this genus into a family of its own: Glaucostegidae (Compagno 2005, Last et al. 2016a).
